doc.after: The Rhyolite historic townsite, maintained by the Bureau of Land Management,[45][46] is "one of the most photographed ghost towns in the West".[47] Ruins include the railroad depot and other buildings, and the Bottle House, which the Famous Players Lasky Corporation, the parent of Paramount Pictures, restored in 1925 for the filming of a silent movie, The Air Mail.[48] The ruins of the Cook Bank Building were used in the 1964 film The Reward and again in 2004 for the filming of The Island.[49] Orion Pictures used Rhyolite for its 1987 science-fiction movie Cherry 2000 depicting the collapse of American society.[50] Six-String Samurai (1998) was another movie using Rhyolite as a setting.[48] The Rhyolite-Bullfrog cemetery, with many wooden headboards, is slightly south of Rhyolite.[51]
